properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain over West Vancouver Island will ease this morning as an atmospheric river aimed at the region moves away. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected to affect the area this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T18:19:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T10:04:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0433107782.2019
Area: Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson, Dryden - Vermilion Bay

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system over the BC interior will exit the province later today. As snow levels continue to rise, snow will change over to rain showers this afternoon. Another 10 cm of snowfall can be expected this morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-18T02:58:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T10:59:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1593189224.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Traffic Hazard Alert For Hwy 16 West Of Wildwood
properties.Summary:
Description: Westbound traffic on Highway 16, west of Wildwood in Yellowhead County between Range Road 100 and Hwy 753, is being rerouted due to a motor vehicle incident. Vehicles travelling in this area need to be cautious of the highway closure and emergency responders on scene as well as traffic being rerouted due the incident. ### Go to www.511.alberta.ca for up to date Road Report information.
Expires: 2019-11-24T05:34:12-07:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Yellowhead County, 2019-11-17T05:32:04-07:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-6108
Area: Yellowhead County
properties.Author: Yellowhead County

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard easing later today. Northerly winds of 50 gusting 70 km/h have been giving blizzard conditions to Naujaat since last evening, with visibilities still quite poor late this morning. Conditions should slowly improve later this afternoon or this evening as the winds start to diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-18T05:59:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T15:29:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1167250094.2019
Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain is expected for the inland sections of the central coast, the Sunshine Coast and Howe Sound. An atmospheric river aimed at North Vancouver Island and the Central Coast will move southward tonight and Sunday morning. Rain will ease by Sunday morning and total rainfall amounts of 50 to 70 mm are expected. Given the tropical origin of the atmospheric river, freezing levels will be on the rise, reaching near 3000 metres for the South Coast and close to 2500 metres for the North Coast. The mild air will result in rain at almost all elevations and steady temperatures overnight. High runoff and rising river levels are likely through the weekend. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-18T00:04:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T08:05:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3947964334.2019
Area: Central Coast - inland sections, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Howe Sound
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Pockets of significantly reduced visibilities in fog are being reported throughout west-central Saskatchewan. The fog will begin to lift this morning. Stay alert for updated bulletins as more regions may be added to the fog advisory. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T17:33:33-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly 100 km/h. Time span: until this afternoon. Location: Canada Bay area. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An area of high pressure entrenched over the Mackenzie basin combined with an approaching low over the Gulf of Alaska will produce strong winds and blizzard conditions to the Dempster highway near the Richardson Mountains. The blizzard will persist today and ease this evening as the wind diminishes. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-18T03:03:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T11:04:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3818527202.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Sustained winds of 70 km/h with gusts to 100 km/h have developed over parts of southern Alberta. Northwestern portions of the foothills are expected to see strong winds of 70 km/h with gusts to 100 km/h briefly this morning before the winds begin to weaken early this afternoon. Winds over the southern foothills are expected to weaken later this afternoon. Strong gusty winds are forecast throughout the mountain parks and foothills regions. Please refer to local forecasts for regions not currently included in this warning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T23:34:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T11:30:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2527271162.2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A moisture-laden Pacific frontal system will bring significant snowfall and the risk of freezing rain to Watson Lake. Snow, heavy at times, will continue until this evening. Total snowfall accumulation will likely exceed 25 cm. There is also the risk of freezing rain or ice pellets this afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-18T03:04:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T11:05:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0796997215.2019
Area: Watson Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the U.S. eastern seaboard could hit Southern Quebec with a mixed bag of precipitation Monday evening. Precipitation is expected to begin as freezing rain before changing over to snow Tuesday morning. Ice accretion could be significant in a few areas making roads and other surfaces slippery. The exact track of this system remains uncertain and, as a result, so do the areas at risk. More details will be provided in future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-18T01:45:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T09:46:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2212901442.2019
